title: Definite matrix
summary: In mathematics, a symmetric matrix M {\displaystyle M} with real entries is  positive-definite if the real number z T M z {\displaystyle z^{\textsf {T}}Mz} is positive for every nonzero real column vector z , {\displaystyle z,} where z T {\displaystyle z^{\textsf {T}}} is the transpose of z {\displaystyle z} .[1] More generally, a Hermitian matrix (that is, a complex matrix equal to its conjugate transpose)  is positive-definite if the real number z ∗ M z {\displaystyle z^{*}Mz} is positive for every nonzero complex column vector z , {\displaystyle z,} where z ∗ {\displaystyle z^{*}} denotes the conjugate transpose of z . {\displaystyle z.}
